title: The Raven
line_text: Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,

title: The Raven
line_text: Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—

title: The Raven
line_text: While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,

title: The Raven
line_text: As of some one gently rapping—rapping at my chamber door.

title: The Raven
line_text: "'Tis some visitor," I muttered, "tapping at my chamber door—

title: The Raven
line_text: Only this and nothing more."

title: The Raven
line_text: Ah, distinctly I remember, it was in the bleak December,

title: The Raven
line_text: And each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.

title: The Raven
line_text: Eagerly I wished the morrow;—vainly I had sought to borrow

title: The Raven
line_text: From my books surcease of sorrow—sorrow for the lost Lenore—

title: The Raven
line_text: For the rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Nameless here for evermore.

title: The Raven
line_text: And the silken sad uncertain rustling of each purple curtain

title: The Raven
line_text: Thrilled me—filled me with fantastic terrors never felt before;

title: The Raven
line_text: So that now, to still the beating of my heart, I stood repeating

title: The Raven
line_text: "'Tis some visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door—

title: The Raven
line_text: Some late visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door;—

title: The Raven
line_text: This it is and nothing more."

title: The Raven
line_text: Presently my soul grew stronger; hesitating then no longer,

title: The Raven
line_text: "Sir," said I, "or Madam, truly your forgiveness I implore;

title: The Raven
line_text: But the fact is I was napping, and so gently you came rapping,

title: The Raven
line_text: And so faintly you came tapping—tapping at my chamber door,

title: The Raven
line_text: That I scarce was sure I heard you"—here I opened wide the door:—

title: The Raven
line_text: Darkness there and nothing more.

title: The Raven
line_text: Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,

title: The Raven
line_text: Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;

title: The Raven
line_text: But the silence was unbroken, and the darkness gave no token,

title: The Raven
line_text: And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, "Lenore!"

title: The Raven
line_text: This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, "Lenore!"

title: The Raven
line_text: Merely this and nothing more.

title: The Raven
line_text: Back into the chamber turning, all my soul within me burning,

title: The Raven
line_text: Soon I heard again a tapping, somewhat louder than before.

title: The Raven
line_text: "Surely," said I, "surely that is something at my window lattice;

title: The Raven
line_text: Let me see, then, what thereat is, and this mystery explore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Let my heart be still a moment, and this mystery explore;—

title: The Raven
line_text: 'Tis the wind and nothing more."

title: The Raven
line_text: Open here I flung the shutter, when, with many a flirt and flutter,

title: The Raven
line_text: In there stepped a stately Raven of the saintly days of yore;

title: The Raven
line_text: Not the least obeisance made he: not an instant stopped or stayed he;

title: The Raven
line_text: But, with mien of lord or lady, perched above my chamber door-

title: The Raven
line_text: Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door—

title: The Raven
line_text: Perched, and sat, and nothing more.

title: The Raven
line_text: Then this ebony bird beguiling my sad fancy into smiling,

title: The Raven
line_text: By the grave and stern decorum of the countenance it wore,

title: The Raven
line_text: "Though thy crest be shorn and shaven, thou," I said, "art sure no craven,

title: The Raven
line_text: Ghastly grim and ancient Raven wandering from the Nightly shore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Tell me what thy lordly name is on the Night's Plutonian shore!"

title: The Raven
line_text: Quoth the Raven, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: Much I marvelled this ungainly fowl to hear discourse so plainly,

title: The Raven
line_text: Though its answer little meaning—little relevancy bore;

title: The Raven
line_text: For we cannot help agreeing that no living human being

title: The Raven
line_text: Ever yet was blessed with seeing bird above his chamber door—

title: The Raven
line_text: Bird or beast upon the sculptured bust above his chamber door,

title: The Raven
line_text: With such name as "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: But the Raven, sitting lonely on that placid bust, spoke only

title: The Raven
line_text: That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.

title: The Raven
line_text: Nothing further then he uttered—not a feather then he fluttered—

title: The Raven
line_text: Till I scarcely more than muttered, "Other friends have flown before—

title: The Raven
line_text: On the morrow he will leave me, as my hopes have flown before."

title: The Raven
line_text: Then the bird said, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: Startled at the stillness broken by reply so aptly spoken,

title: The Raven
line_text: "Doubtless," said I, "what it utters is its only stock and store,

title: The Raven
line_text: Caught from some unhappy master whom unmerciful Disaster

title: The Raven
line_text: Followed fast and followed faster till his songs one burden bore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Till the dirges of his Hope the melancholy burden bore

title: The Raven
line_text: Of 'Never—nevermore.'"

title: The Raven
line_text: But the Raven still beguiling all my sad soul into smiling,

title: The Raven
line_text: Straight I wheeled a cushioned seat in front of bird and bust and door;

title: The Raven
line_text: Then, upon the velvet sinking, I betook myself to linking

title: The Raven
line_text: Fancy unto fancy, thinking what this ominous bird of yore—

title: The Raven
line_text: What this grim, ungainly, ghastly, gaunt, and ominous bird of yore

title: The Raven
line_text: Meant in croaking "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: This I sat engaged in guessing, but no syllable expressing

title: The Raven
line_text: To the fowl whose fiery eyes now burned into my bosom's core;

title: The Raven
line_text: This and more I sat divining, with my head at ease reclining

title: The Raven
line_text: On the cushion's velvet lining that the lamp-light gloated o'er,

title: The Raven
line_text: But whose velvet violet lining with the lamp-light gloating o'er, She shall press, ah, nevermore!

title: The Raven
line_text: Then, methought, the air grew denser, perfumed from an unseen censer

title: The Raven
line_text: Swung by Seraphim whose foot-falls tinkled on the tufted floor.

title: The Raven
line_text: "Wretch," I cried, "thy God hath lent thee—by these angels he hath sent thee

title: The Raven
line_text: Respite—respite and nepenthé from thy memories of Lenore!

title: The Raven
line_text: Quaff, oh quaff this kind nepenthé, and forget this lost Lenore!"

title: The Raven
line_text: Quoth the Raven, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: "Prophet!" said I, "thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!—

title: The Raven
line_text: Whether Tempter sent, or whether tempest tossed thee here ashore,

title: The Raven
line_text: Desolate yet all undaunted, on this desert land enchanted—

title: The Raven
line_text: On this home by Horror haunted—tell me truly, I implore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Is there— is there balm in Gilead?—tell me—tell me, I implore!"

title: The Raven
line_text: Quoth the Raven, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: "Prophet!" said I, "thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!

title: The Raven
line_text: By that Heaven that bends above us — by that God we both adore—

title: The Raven
line_text: Tell this soul with sorrow laden if, within the distant Aidenn,

title: The Raven
line_text: It shall clasp a sainted maiden whom the angels name Lenore —

title: The Raven
line_text: Clasp a rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore."

title: The Raven
line_text: Quoth the Raven, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: "Be that word our sign of parting, bird or fiend!" I shrieked, upstarting—

title: The Raven
line_text: "Get thee back into the tempest and the Night's Plutonian shore!

title: The Raven
line_text: Leave no black plume as a token of that lie thy soul hath spoken!

title: The Raven
line_text: Leave my loneliness unbroken!—quit the bust above my door!

title: The Raven
line_text: Take thy beak from out my heart, and take thy form from off my door!"

title: The Raven
line_text: Quoth the Raven, "Nevermore."

title: The Raven
line_text: And the Raven, never flitting, still is sitting, still is sitting

title: The Raven
line_text: On the pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door;

title: The Raven
line_text: And his eyes have all the seeming of a demon's that is dreaming,

title: The Raven
line_text: And the lamp-light o'er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor;

title: The Raven
line_text: And my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor

title: The Raven
line_text: Shall be lifted—nevermore! Published, 1845. Note Contents

title: Ulalume
line_text: The skies they were ashen and sober;

title: Ulalume
line_text: The leaves they were crisped and sere—

title: Ulalume
line_text: The leaves they were withering and sere;

title: Ulalume
line_text: It was night in the lonesome October

title: Ulalume
line_text: Of my most immemorial year;

title: Ulalume
line_text: It was hard by the dim lake of Auber,

title: Ulalume
line_text: In the misty mid region of Weir—

title: Ulalume
line_text: It was down by the dank tarn of Auber,

title: Ulalume
line_text: In the ghoul-haunted woodland of Weir.

title: Ulalume
line_text: Here once, through an alley Titanic.

title: Ulalume
line_text: Of cypress, I roamed with my Soul—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Of cypress, with Psyche, my Soul.

title: Ulalume
line_text: These were days when my heart was volcanic

title: Ulalume
line_text: As the scoriac rivers that roll—

title: Ulalume
line_text: As the lavas that restlessly roll

title: Ulalume
line_text: Their sulphurous currents down Yaanek

title: Ulalume
line_text: In the ultimate climes of the pole—

title: Ulalume
line_text: That groan as they roll down Mount Yaanek

title: Ulalume
line_text: In the realms of the boreal pole.

title: Ulalume
line_text: Our talk had been serious and sober,

title: Ulalume
line_text: But our thoughts they were palsied and sere—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Our memories were treacherous and sere—

title: Ulalume
line_text: For we knew not the month was October,

title: Ulalume
line_text: And we marked not the night of the year—

title: Ulalume
line_text: (Ah, night of all nights in the year!)

title: Ulalume
line_text: We noted not the dim lake of Auber—

title: Ulalume
line_text: (Though once we had journeyed down here)—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Remembered not the dank tarn of Auber,

title: Ulalume
line_text: Nor the ghoul-haunted woodland of Weir.

title: Ulalume
line_text: And now as the night was senescent

title: Ulalume
line_text: And star-dials pointed to morn—

title: Ulalume
line_text: As the sun-dials hinted of morn—

title: Ulalume
line_text: At the end of our path a liquescent

title: Ulalume
line_text: And nebulous lustre was born,

title: Ulalume
line_text: Out of which a miraculous crescent

title: Ulalume
line_text: Arose with a duplicate horn—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Astarte's bediamonded crescent

title: Ulalume
line_text: Distinct with its duplicate horn.

title: Ulalume
line_text: And I said—"She is warmer than Dian:

title: Ulalume
line_text: She rolls through an ether of sighs—

title: Ulalume
line_text: She revels in a region of sighs:

title: Ulalume
line_text: She has seen that the tears are not dry on

title: Ulalume
line_text: These cheeks, where the worm never dies,

title: Ulalume
line_text: And has come past the stars of the Lion

title: Ulalume
line_text: To point us the path to the skies—

title: Ulalume
line_text: To the Lethean peace of the skies—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Come up, in despite of the Lion,

title: Ulalume
line_text: To shine on us with her bright eyes—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Come up through the lair of the Lion,

title: Ulalume
line_text: With love in her luminous eyes."

title: Ulalume
line_text: But Psyche, uplifting her finger,

title: Ulalume
line_text: Said—"Sadly this star I mistrust—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Her pallor I strangely mistrust:—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Oh, hasten!—oh, let us not linger!

title: Ulalume
line_text: Oh, fly!—let us fly!—for we must."

title: Ulalume
line_text: In terror she spoke, letting sink her

title: Ulalume
line_text: Wings till they trailed in the dust—

title: Ulalume
line_text: In agony sobbed, letting sink her

title: Ulalume
line_text: Plumes till they trailed in the dust—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Till they sorrowfully trailed in the dust.

title: Ulalume
line_text: I replied—"This is nothing but dreaming:

title: Ulalume
line_text: Let us on by this tremulous light!

title: Ulalume
line_text: Let us bathe in this crystalline light!

title: Ulalume
line_text: Its Sibyllic splendor is beaming

title: Ulalume
line_text: With Hope and in Beauty to-night:—

title: Ulalume
line_text: See!—it flickers up the sky through the night!

title: Ulalume
line_text: Ah, we safely may trust to its gleaming,

title: Ulalume
line_text: And be sure it will lead us aright—

title: Ulalume
line_text: We safely may trust to a gleaming

title: Ulalume
line_text: That cannot but guide us aright,

title: Ulalume
line_text: Since it flickers up to Heaven through the night."

title: Ulalume
line_text: Thus I pacified Psyche and kissed her,

title: Ulalume
line_text: And tempted her out of her gloom—

title: Ulalume
line_text: And conquered her scruples and gloom;

title: Ulalume
line_text: And we passed to the end of a vista,

title: Ulalume
line_text: But were stopped by the door of a tomb—

title: Ulalume
line_text: By the door of a legended tomb;

title: Ulalume
line_text: And I said—"What is written, sweet sister,

title: Ulalume
line_text: On the door of this legended tomb?"

title: Ulalume
line_text: She replied—"Ulalume—Ulalume—

title: Ulalume
line_text: 'Tis the vault of thy lost Ulalume!"

title: Ulalume
line_text: Then my heart it grew ashen and sober

title: Ulalume
line_text: As the leaves that were crisped and sere—

title: Ulalume
line_text: As the leaves that were withering and sere;

title: Ulalume
line_text: And I cried—"It was surely October

title: Ulalume
line_text: On this very night of last year

title: Ulalume
line_text: That I journeyed—I journeyed down here—

title: Ulalume
line_text: That I brought a dread burden down here!

title: Ulalume
line_text: On this night of all nights in the year,

title: Ulalume
line_text: Ah, what demon has tempted me here?

title: Ulalume
line_text: Well I know, now, this dim lake of Auber—

title: Ulalume
line_text: This misty mid region of Weir—

title: Ulalume
line_text: Well I know, now, this dank tarn of Auber,—

title: Ulalume
line_text: This ghoul-haunted woodland of Weir." 1847 Note Contents

title: To Helen
line_text: I saw thee once—once only—years ago:

title: To Helen
line_text: I must not say how many—but not many.

title: To Helen
line_text: It was a July midnight; and from out

title: To Helen
line_text: A full-orbed moon, that, like thine own soul, soaring,

title: To Helen
line_text: Sought a precipitate pathway up through heaven,

title: To Helen
line_text: There fell a silvery-silken veil of light,

title: To Helen
line_text: With quietude, and sultriness and slumber,

title: To Helen
line_text: Upon the upturn'd faces of a thousand

title: To Helen
line_text: Roses that grew in an enchanted garden,

title: To Helen
line_text: Where no wind dared to stir, unless on tiptoe—

title: To Helen
line_text: Fell on the upturn'd faces of these roses

title: To Helen
line_text: That gave out, in return for the love-light,

title: To Helen
line_text: Their odorous souls in an ecstatic death—

title: To Helen
line_text: Fell on the upturn'd faces of these roses

title: To Helen
line_text: That smiled and died in this parterre, enchanted

title: To Helen
line_text: By thee, and by the poetry of thy presence.

title: To Helen
line_text: Clad all in white, upon a violet bank

title: To Helen
line_text: I saw thee half-reclining; while the moon

title: To Helen
line_text: Fell on the upturn'd faces of the roses,

title: To Helen
line_text: And on thine own, upturn'd—alas, in sorrow!

title: To Helen
line_text: Was it not Fate, that, on this July midnight—

title: To Helen
line_text: Was it not Fate (whose name is also Sorrow),

title: To Helen
line_text: That bade me pause before that garden-gate,

title: To Helen
line_text: To breathe the incense of those slumbering roses?

title: To Helen
line_text: No footstep stirred: the hated world all slept,

title: To Helen
line_text: Save only thee and me—(O Heaven!—O God!

title: To Helen
line_text: How my heart beats in coupling those two words!)—

title: To Helen
line_text: Save only thee and me. I paused—I looked—

title: To Helen
line_text: And in an instant all things disappeared.

title: To Helen
line_text: (Ah, bear in mind this garden was enchanted!)

title: To Helen
line_text: The pearly lustre of the moon went out:

title: To Helen
line_text: The mossy banks and the meandering paths,

title: To Helen
line_text: The happy flowers and the repining trees,

title: To Helen
line_text: Were seen no more: the very roses' odors

title: To Helen
line_text: Died in the arms of the adoring airs.

title: To Helen
line_text: All—all expired save thee—save less than thou:

title: To Helen
line_text: Save only the divine light in thine eyes—

title: To Helen
line_text: Save but the soul in thine uplifted eyes.

title: To Helen
line_text: I saw but them—they were the world to me.

title: To Helen
line_text: I saw but them—saw only them for hours—

title: To Helen
line_text: Saw only them until the moon went down.

title: To Helen
line_text: What wild heart-histories seemed to lie unwritten

title: To Helen
line_text: Upon those crystalline, celestial spheres!

title: To Helen
line_text: How dark a woe! yet how sublime a hope!

title: To Helen
line_text: How silently serene a sea of pride!

title: To Helen
line_text: How daring an ambition! yet how deep—

title: To Helen
line_text: How fathomless a capacity for love!

title: To Helen
line_text: But now, at length, dear Dian sank from sight,

title: To Helen
line_text: Into a western couch of thunder-cloud;

title: To Helen
line_text: And thou, a ghost, amid the entombing trees

title: To Helen
line_text: Didst glide away. Only thine eyes remained. They would not go—they never yet have gone.

title: To Helen
line_text: Lighting my lonely pathway home that night, They have not left me (as my hopes have) since.

title: To Helen
line_text: They follow me—they lead me through the years.

title: To Helen
line_text: They are my ministers—yet I their slave.

title: To Helen
line_text: Their office is to illumine and enkindle—

title: To Helen
line_text: My duty, to be saved by their bright light,

title: To Helen
line_text: And purified in their electric fire,

title: To Helen
line_text: And sanctified in their elysian fire.

title: To Helen
line_text: They fill my soul with Beauty (which is Hope),

title: To Helen
line_text: And are far up in Heaven—the stars I kneel to

title: To Helen
line_text: In the sad, silent watches of my night;

title: To Helen
line_text: While even in the meridian glare of day

title: To Helen
line_text: I see them still—two sweetly scintillant

title: To Helen
line_text: Venuses, unextinguished by the sun! 1846 Note Contents

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: It was many and many a year ago,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In a kingdom by the sea,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: That a maiden there lived whom you may know

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: By the name of Annabel Lee ;

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And this maiden she lived with no other thought

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Than to love and be loved by me. I was a child and she was a child,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In this kingdom by the sea:

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: But we loved with a love that was more than love—

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: I and my Annabel Lee ;

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: With a love that the winged seraphs of heaven

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Coveted her and me.

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And this was the reason that, long ago,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In this kingdom by the sea,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: A wind blew out of a cloud, chilling

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: My beautiful Annabel Lee ;

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: So that her highborn kinsmen came

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And bore her away from me,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: To shut her up in a sepulchre

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In this kingdom by the sea.

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: The angels, not half so happy in heaven,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Went envying her and me—

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Yes!—that was the reason (as all men know,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In this kingdom by the sea)

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: That the wind came out of the cloud by night,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Chilling and killing my Annabel Lee .

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: But our love it was stronger by far than the love

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of those who were older than we—

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of many far wiser than we—

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And neither the angels in heaven above,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Nor the demons down under the sea,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Can ever dissever my soul from the soul

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee .

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: For the moon never beams without bringing me dreams

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee ;

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And the stars never rise but I see the bright eyes

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of the beautiful Annabel Lee ;

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: And so, all the night-tide, I lie down by the side

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: Of my darling, my darling, my life and my bride,

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In her sepulchre there by the sea—

title: Annabel Lee
line_text: In her tomb by the side of the sea. Note Contents

title: A Valentine
line_text: For her this rhyme is penned, whose luminous eyes,

title: A Valentine
line_text: Brightly expressive as the twins of Leda,

title: A Valentine
line_text: Shall find her own sweet name, that, nestling lies

title: A Valentine
line_text: Upon the page, enwrapped from every reader.

title: A Valentine
line_text: Search narrowly the lines!—they hold a treasure

title: A Valentine
line_text: Divine—a talisman—an amulet

title: A Valentine
line_text: That must be worn at heart . Search well the measure—

title: A Valentine
line_text: The words—the syllables! Do not forget

title: A Valentine
line_text: The trivialest point, or you may lose your labor!

title: A Valentine
line_text: And yet there is in this no Gordian knot

title: A Valentine
line_text: Which one might not undo without a sabre,

title: A Valentine
line_text: If one could merely comprehend the plot.

title: A Valentine
line_text: Enwritten upon the leaf where now are peering

title: A Valentine
line_text: Eyes scintillating soul, there lie perdus Three eloquent words oft uttered in the hearing

title: A Valentine
line_text: Of poets by poets—as the name is a poet's, too.

title: A Valentine
line_text: Its letters, although naturally lying

title: A Valentine
line_text: Like the knight Pinto—Mendez Ferdinando—

title: A Valentine
line_text: Still form a synonym for Truth—Cease trying!

title: A Valentine
line_text: You will not read the riddle, though you do the best you can do. 1846 {To discover the names in this and the following poem, read the first

title: A Valentine
line_text: letter of the first line in connection with the second letter of the

title: A Valentine
line_text: second line, the third letter of the third line, the fourth, of the

title: A Valentine
line_text: fourth and so on, to the end.} Note Contents

title: An Enigma
line_text: "Seldom we find," says Solomon Don Dunce,

title: An Enigma
line_text: "Half an idea in the profoundest sonnet.

title: An Enigma
line_text: Through all the flimsy things we see at once

title: An Enigma
line_text: As easily as through a Naples bonnet—

title: An Enigma
line_text: Trash of all trash!—how can a lady don it?

title: An Enigma
line_text: Yet heavier far than your Petrarchan stuff—

title: An Enigma
line_text: Owl-downy nonsense that the faintest puff

title: An Enigma
line_text: Twirls into trunk-paper the while you con it."

title: An Enigma
line_text: And, veritably, Sol is right enough.

title: An Enigma
line_text: The general tuckermanities are arrant

title: An Enigma
line_text: Bubbles—ephemeral and so transparent—

title: An Enigma
line_text: But this is , now—you may depend upon it—

title: An Enigma
line_text: Stable, opaque, immortal—all by dint

title: An Enigma
line_text: Of the dear names that lie concealed within't. {See comment after previous poem.} Note Contents

title: To My Mother
line_text: Because I feel that, in the Heavens above,

title: To My Mother
line_text: The angels, whispering to one another,

title: To My Mother
line_text: Can find, among their burning terms of love,

title: To My Mother
line_text: None so devotional as that of "Mother,"

title: To My Mother
line_text: Therefore by that dear name I long have called you—

title: To My Mother
line_text: You who are more than mother unto me,

title: To My Mother
line_text: And fill my heart of hearts, where Death installed you,

title: To My Mother
line_text: In setting my Virginia's spirit free.

title: To My Mother
line_text: My mother—my own mother, who died early,

title: To My Mother
line_text: Was but the mother of myself; but you

title: To My Mother
line_text: Are mother to the one I loved so dearly,

title: To My Mother
line_text: And thus are dearer than the mother I knew

title: To My Mother
line_text: By that infinity with which my wife

title: To My Mother
line_text: Was dearer to my soul than its soul-life. 1849 {The above was addressed to the poet's mother-in-law, Mrs. Clemm.—Ed.} Note Contents

title: For Annie
line_text: Thank Heaven! the crisis—

title: For Annie
line_text: The danger is past,

title: For Annie
line_text: And the lingering illness

title: For Annie
line_text: Is over at last—

title: For Annie
line_text: And the fever called "Living"

title: For Annie
line_text: Is conquered at last.

title: For Annie
line_text: Sadly, I know,

title: For Annie
line_text: I am shorn of my strength,

title: For Annie
line_text: And no muscle I move

title: For Annie
line_text: As I lie at full length—

title: For Annie
line_text: But no matter!—I feel

title: For Annie
line_text: I am better at length.

title: For Annie
line_text: And I rest so composedly,

title: For Annie
line_text: Now in my bed,

title: For Annie
line_text: That any beholder

title: For Annie
line_text: Might fancy me dead—

title: For Annie
line_text: Might start at beholding me

title: For Annie
line_text: Thinking me dead.

title: For Annie
line_text: The moaning and groaning,

title: For Annie
line_text: The sighing and sobbing,

title: For Annie
line_text: Are quieted now,

title: For Annie
line_text: With that horrible throbbing

title: For Annie
line_text: At heart:—ah, that horrible,

title: For Annie
line_text: Horrible throbbing!

title: For Annie
line_text: The sickness—the nausea—

title: For Annie
line_text: The pitiless pain—

title: For Annie
line_text: Have ceased, with the fever

title: For Annie
line_text: That maddened my brain—

title: For Annie
line_text: With the fever called "Living"

title: For Annie
line_text: That burned in my brain.

title: For Annie
line_text: And oh! of all tortures That torture the worst

title: For Annie
line_text: Has abated—the terrible

title: For Annie
line_text: Torture of thirst,

title: For Annie
line_text: For the naphthaline river

title: For Annie
line_text: Of Passion accurst:—

title: For Annie
line_text: I have drank of a water

title: For Annie
line_text: That quenches all thirst:—

title: For Annie
line_text: Of a water that flows,

title: For Annie
line_text: With a lullaby sound,

title: For Annie
line_text: From a spring but a very few

title: For Annie
line_text: Feet under ground—

title: For Annie
line_text: From a cavern not very far

title: For Annie
line_text: Down under ground.

title: For Annie
line_text: And ah! let it never

title: For Annie
line_text: Be foolishly said

title: For Annie
line_text: That my room it is gloomy

title: For Annie
line_text: And narrow my bed—

title: For Annie
line_text: For man never slept

title: For Annie
line_text: In a different bed;

title: For Annie
line_text: And, to sleep , you must slumber

title: For Annie
line_text: In just such a bed.

title: For Annie
line_text: My tantalized spirit

title: For Annie
line_text: Here blandly reposes,

title: For Annie
line_text: Forgetting, or never

title: For Annie
line_text: Regretting its roses—

title: For Annie
line_text: Its old agitations

title: For Annie
line_text: Of myrtles and roses:

title: For Annie
line_text: For now, while so quietly

title: For Annie
line_text: Lying, it fancies

title: For Annie
line_text: A holier odor

title: For Annie
line_text: About it, of pansies—

title: For Annie
line_text: A rosemary odor,

title: For Annie
line_text: Commingled with pansies—

title: For Annie
line_text: With rue and the beautiful

title: For Annie
line_text: Puritan pansies.

title: For Annie
line_text: And so it lies happily,

title: For Annie
line_text: Bathing in many

title: For Annie
line_text: A dream of the truth

title: For Annie
line_text: And the beauty of Annie—

title: For Annie
line_text: Drowned in a bath

title: For Annie
line_text: Of the tresses of Annie.

title: For Annie
line_text: She tenderly kissed me,

title: For Annie
line_text: She fondly caressed,

title: For Annie
line_text: And then I fell gently

title: For Annie
line_text: To sleep on her breast—

title: For Annie
line_text: Deeply to sleep

title: For Annie
line_text: From the heaven of her breast.

title: For Annie
line_text: When the light was extinguished,

title: For Annie
line_text: She covered me warm,

title: For Annie
line_text: And she prayed to the angels

title: For Annie
line_text: To keep me from harm—

title: For Annie
line_text: To the queen of the angels

title: For Annie
line_text: To shield me from harm.

title: For Annie
line_text: And I lie so composedly,

title: For Annie
line_text: Now in my bed

title: For Annie
line_text: (Knowing her love)

title: For Annie
line_text: That you fancy me dead—

title: For Annie
line_text: And I rest so contentedly,

title: For Annie
line_text: Now in my bed,

title: For Annie
line_text: (With her love at my breast)

title: For Annie
line_text: That you fancy me dead—

title: For Annie
line_text: That you shudder to look at me.

title: For Annie
line_text: Thinking me dead.

title: For Annie
line_text: But my heart it is brighter

title: For Annie
line_text: Than all of the many

title: For Annie
line_text: Stars in the sky,

title: For Annie
line_text: For it sparkles with Annie—

title: For Annie
line_text: It glows with the light

title: For Annie
line_text: Of the love of my Annie—

title: For Annie
line_text: With the thought of the light

title: For Annie
line_text: Of the eyes of my Annie. 1849 Note Contents

title: To F——
line_text: Beloved! amid the earnest woes

title: To F——
line_text: That crowd around my earthly path—

title: To F——
line_text: (Drear path, alas! where grows

title: To F——
line_text: Not even one lonely rose)—

title: To F——
line_text: My soul at least a solace hath

title: To F——
line_text: In dreams of thee, and therein knows

title: To F——
line_text: An Eden of bland repose.

title: To F——
line_text: And thus thy memory is to me

title: To F——
line_text: Like some enchanted far-off isle

title: To F——
line_text: In some tumultuous sea—

title: To F——
line_text: Some ocean throbbing far and free

title: To F——
line_text: With storm—but where meanwhile

title: To F——
line_text: Serenest skies continually

title: To F——
line_text: Just o'er that one bright inland smile. 1845 Note Contents

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: Thou wouldst be loved?—then let thy heart

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: From its present pathway part not;

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: Being everything which now thou art,

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: Be nothing which thou art not.

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: So with the world thy gentle ways,

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: Thy grace, thy more than beauty,

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: Shall be an endless theme of praise.

title: To Frances S. Osgood
line_text: And love a simple duty. 1845 Note Contents

title: Eldorado
line_text: Gaily bedight,

title: Eldorado
line_text: A gallant knight,

title: Eldorado
line_text: In sunshine and in shadow,

title: Eldorado
line_text: Had journeyed long,

title: Eldorado
line_text: Singing a song,

title: Eldorado
line_text: In search of Eldorado.

title: Eldorado
line_text: But he grew old—

title: Eldorado
line_text: This knight so bold—

title: Eldorado
line_text: And o'er his heart a shadow

title: Eldorado
line_text: Fell as he found

title: Eldorado
line_text: No spot of ground

title: Eldorado
line_text: That looked like Eldorado.

title: Eldorado
line_text: And, as his strength

title: Eldorado
line_text: Failed him at length,

title: Eldorado
line_text: He met a pilgrim shadow—

title: Eldorado
line_text: "Shadow," said he,

title: Eldorado
line_text: "Where can it be—

title: Eldorado
line_text: This land of Eldorado?"

title: Eldorado
line_text: "Over the Mountains

title: Eldorado
line_text: Of the Moon,

title: Eldorado
line_text: Down the Valley of the Shadow,

title: Eldorado
line_text: Ride, boldly ride,"

title: Eldorado
line_text: The shade replied,

title: Eldorado
line_text: "If you seek for Eldorado!" 1849 Note Contents

title: Eulalie
line_text: I dwelt alone

title: Eulalie
line_text: In a world of moan,

title: Eulalie
line_text: And my soul was a stagnant tide,

title: Eulalie
line_text: Till the fair and gentle Eulalie became my blushing bride—

title: Eulalie
line_text: Till the yellow-haired young Eulalie became my smiling bride.

title: Eulalie
line_text: Ah, less—less bright

title: Eulalie
line_text: The stars of the night

title: Eulalie
line_text: Than the eyes of the radiant girl!

title: Eulalie
line_text: And never a flake

title: Eulalie
line_text: That the vapor can make

title: Eulalie
line_text: With the moon-tints of purple and pearl,

title: Eulalie
line_text: Can vie with the modest Eulalie's most unregarded curl—

title: Eulalie
line_text: Can compare with the bright-eyed Eulalie's most humble and careless curl.

title: Eulalie
line_text: Now Doubt—now Pain

title: Eulalie
line_text: Come never again,

title: Eulalie
line_text: For her soul gives me sigh for sigh,

title: Eulalie
line_text: And all day long

title: Eulalie
line_text: Shines, bright and strong,

title: Eulalie
line_text: Astarté within the sky,

title: Eulalie
line_text: While ever to her dear Eulalie upturns her matron eye—

title: Eulalie
line_text: While ever to her young Eulalie upturns her violet eye. 1845 Note Contents

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Take this kiss upon the brow!

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: And, in parting from you now,

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Thus much let me avow—

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: You are not wrong, who deem

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: That my days have been a dream:

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Yet if hope has flown away

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: In a night, or in a day,

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: In a vision or in none,

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Is it therefore the less gone ? All that we see or seem

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Is but a dream within a dream.

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: I stand amid the roar

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Of a surf-tormented shore,

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: And I hold within my hand

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Grains of the golden sand—

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: How few! yet how they creep

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Through my fingers to the deep

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: While I weep—while I weep!

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: O God! can I not grasp

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Them with a tighter clasp?

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: O God! can I not save One from the pitiless wave?

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: Is all that we see or seem

title: A Dream within a Dream
line_text: But a dream within a dream? 1849 Note Contents

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Of all who hail thy presence as the morning—

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Of all to whom thine absence is the night—

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: The blotting utterly from out high heaven

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: The sacred sun—of all who, weeping, bless thee

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Hourly for hope—for life—ah, above all,

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: For the resurrection of deep buried faith

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: In truth, in virtue, in humanity—

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Of all who, on despair's unhallowed bed

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Lying down to die, have suddenly arisen

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: At thy soft-murmured words, "Let there be light!"

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: At thy soft-murmured words that were fulfilled

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: In thy seraphic glancing of thine eyes—

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Of all who owe thee most, whose gratitude

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Nearest resembles worship,—oh, remember

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: The truest, the most fervently devoted,

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: And think that these weak lines are written by him—

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: By him who, as he pens them, thrills to think

title: Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: His spirit is communing with an angel's. 1847 Note Contents

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Not long ago, the writer of these lines,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: In the mad pride of intellectuality,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Maintained "the power of words"—denied that ever

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: A thought arose within the human brain

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Beyond the utterance of the human tongue:

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: And now, as if in mockery of that boast,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Two words—two foreign soft dissyllables—

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Italian tones, made only to be murmured

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: By angels dreaming in the moonlit "dew

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: That hangs like chains of pearl on Hermon hill,"—

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Have stirred from out the abysses of his heart,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Unthought-like thoughts that are the souls of thought,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Richer, far wilder, far diviner visions

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Than even the seraph harper, Israfel,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: (Who has "the sweetest voice of all God's creatures,")

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Could hope to utter. And I! my spells are broken.

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: The pen falls powerless from my shivering hand.

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: With thy dear name as text, though hidden by thee,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: I cannot write—I cannot speak or think—

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Alas, I cannot feel; for 'tis not feeling,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: This standing motionless upon the golden

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Threshold of the wide-open gate of dreams,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Gazing, entranced, adown the gorgeous vista,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: And thrilling as I see, upon the right,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Upon the left, and all the way along,

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: Amid empurpled vapors, far away

title: (2) To Marie Louise (Shew)
line_text: To where the prospect terminates— thee only! Note Contents

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Lo! Death has reared himself a throne

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: In a strange city lying alone

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Far down within the dim West,

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Where the good and the bad and the worst and the best

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Have gone to their eternal rest.

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: There shrines and palaces and towers

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: (Time-eaten towers and tremble not!)

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Resemble nothing that is ours.

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Around, by lifting winds forgot,

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: Resignedly beneath the sky

title: The City in the Sea
line_text: The melancholy waters lie.

title: The City in the Sea

line_text: While in the wild wood I did lie,

title: Romance
line_text: A child—with a most knowing eye.

title: Romance
line_text: Of late, eternal Condor years

title: Romance
line_text: So shake the very Heaven on high

title: Romance
line_text: With tumult as they thunder by,

title: Romance
line_text: I have no time for idle cares

title: Romance
line_text: Though gazing on the unquiet sky.

title: Romance
line_text: And when an hour with calmer wings

title: Romance
line_text: Its down upon my spirit flings—

title: Romance
line_text: That little time with lyre and rhyme

title: Romance
line_text: To while away—forbidden things!

title: Romance
line_text: My heart would feel to be a crime

title: Romance
line_text: Unless it trembled with the strings. 1829 Contents p. 2

title: Fairyland
line_text: Dim vales—and shadowy floods—

title: Fairyland
line_text: And cloudy-looking woods,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Whose forms we can't discover

title: Fairyland
line_text: For the tears that drip all over

title: Fairyland
line_text: Huge moons there wax and wane—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Again—again—again—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Every moment of the night—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Forever changing places—

title: Fairyland
line_text: And they put out the star-light

title: Fairyland
line_text: With the breath from their pale faces.

title: Fairyland
line_text: About twelve by the moon-dial

title: Fairyland
line_text: One more filmy than the rest

title: Fairyland
line_text: (A kind which, upon trial,

title: Fairyland
line_text: They have found to be the best)

title: Fairyland
line_text: Comes down—still down—and down

title: Fairyland
line_text: With its centre on the crown

title: Fairyland
line_text: Of a mountain's eminence,

title: Fairyland
line_text: While its wide circumference

title: Fairyland
line_text: In easy drapery falls

title: Fairyland
line_text: Over hamlets, over halls,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Wherever they may be—

title: Fairyland
line_text: O'er the strange woods—o'er the sea—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Over spirits on the wing—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Over every drowsy thing—

title: Fairyland
line_text: And buries them up quite

title: Fairyland
line_text: In a labyrinth of light—

title: Fairyland
line_text: And then, how deep!—O, deep!

title: Fairyland
line_text: Is the passion of their sleep.

title: Fairyland
line_text: In the morning they arise,

title: Fairyland
line_text: And their moony covering

title: Fairyland
line_text: Is soaring in the skies,

title: Fairyland
line_text: With the tempests as they toss,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Like—almost any thing—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Or a yellow Albatross.

title: Fairyland
line_text: They use that moon no more

title: Fairyland
line_text: For the same end as before—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Videlicet a tent—

title: Fairyland
line_text: Which I think extravagant:

title: Fairyland
line_text: Its atomies, however,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Into a shower dissever,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Of which those butterflies,

title: Fairyland
line_text: Of Earth, who seek the skies,

title: Fairyland
line_text: And so come down again

title: Fairyland
line_text: (Never-contented thing!)

title: Fairyland
line_text: Have brought a specimen

title: Fairyland
line_text: Upon their quivering wings. 1831 Contents p. 2

title: The Lake
line_text: In spring of youth it was my lot

title: The Lake
line_text: To haunt of the wide world a spot

title: The Lake
line_text: The which I could not love the less—

title: The Lake
line_text: So lovely was the loneliness

title: The Lake
line_text: Of a wild lake, with black rock bound,

title: The Lake
line_text: And the tall pines that towered around.

title: The Lake
line_text: But when the Night had thrown her pall

title: The Lake
line_text: Upon the spot, as upon all,

title: The Lake
line_text: And the mystic wind went by

title: The Lake
line_text: Murmuring in melody—

title: The Lake
line_text: Then—ah, then, I would awake

title: The Lake
line_text: To the terror of the lone lake.

title: The Lake
line_text: Yet that terror was not fright,

title: The Lake
line_text: But a tremulous delight—

title: The Lake
line_text: A feeling not the jewelled mine

title: The Lake
line_text: Could teach or bribe me to define—

title: The Lake
line_text: Nor Love—although the Love were thine.

title: The Lake
line_text: Death was in that poisonous wave,

title: The Lake
line_text: And in its gulf a fitting grave

title: The Lake
line_text: For him who thence could solace bring

title: The Lake
line_text: To his lone imagining—

title: The Lake
line_text: Whose solitary soul could make

title: The Lake
line_text: An Eden of that dim lake. 1827 Contents p. 2

title: Evening Star
line_text: 'Twas noontide of summer,

title: Evening Star
line_text: And midtime of night,

title: Evening Star
line_text: And stars, in their orbits,

title: Evening Star
line_text: Shone pale, through the light

title: Evening Star
line_text: Of the brighter, cold moon.

title: Evening Star
line_text: 'Mid planets her slaves,

title: Evening Star
line_text: Herself in the Heavens,

title: Evening Star
line_text: Her beam on the waves.

title: Evening Star
line_text: I gazed awhile

title: Evening Star
line_text: On her cold smile;

title: Evening Star
line_text: Too cold—too cold for me—

title: Evening Star
line_text: There passed, as a shroud,

title: Evening Star
line_text: A fleecy cloud,

title: Evening Star
line_text: And I turned away to thee,

title: Evening Star
line_text: Proud Evening Star,

title: Evening Star
line_text: In thy glory afar

title: Evening Star
line_text: And dearer thy beam shall be;

title: Evening Star
line_text: For joy to my heart

title: Evening Star
line_text: Is the proud part

title: Evening Star
line_text: Thou bearest in Heaven at night,

title: Evening Star
line_text: And more I admire

title: Evening Star
line_text: Thy distant fire,

title: Evening Star
line_text: Than that colder, lowly light. 1827 Contents p. 2

title: Imitation
line_text: A dark unfathomed tide

title: Imitation
line_text: Of interminable pride—

title: Imitation
line_text: A mystery, and a dream,

title: Imitation
line_text: Should my early life seem;

title: Imitation
line_text: I say that dream was fraught

title: Imitation
line_text: With a wild and waking thought

title: Imitation
line_text: Of beings that have been,

title: Imitation
line_text: Which my spirit hath not seen,

title: Imitation
line_text: Had I let them pass me by,

title: Imitation
line_text: With a dreaming eye!

title: Imitation
line_text: Let none of earth inherit

title: Imitation
line_text: That vision on my spirit;

title: Imitation
line_text: Those thoughts I would control,

title: Imitation
line_text: As a spell upon his soul:

title: Imitation
line_text: For that bright hope at last

title: Imitation
line_text: And that light time have past,

title: Imitation
line_text: And my wordly rest hath gone

title: Imitation
line_text: With a sigh as it passed on:

title: Imitation
line_text: I care not though it perish

title: Imitation
line_text: With a thought I then did cherish. 1827 Contents p. 3

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: I The happiest day—the happiest hour

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: My seared and blighted heart hath known,

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: The highest hope of pride and power,

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: I feel hath flown. II Of power! said I? Yes! such I ween

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: But they have vanished long, alas!

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: The visions of my youth have been—

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: But let them pass. III And pride, what have I now with thee?

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: Another brow may ev'n inherit

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: The venom thou hast poured on me—

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: Be still my spirit! IV The happiest day—the happiest hour

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: Mine eyes shall see—have ever seen

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: The brightest glance of pride and power

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: I feel have been: V But were that hope of pride and power

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: Now offered with the pain

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: Ev'n then I felt—that brightest hour

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: I would not live again: VI For on its wing was dark alloy

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: And as it fluttered—fell

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: An essence—powerful to destroy

title: "The Happiest Day"
line_text: A soul that knew it well. 1827 Contents p. 3

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Hymn to Aristogeiton and Harmodius I Wreathed in myrtle, my sword I'll conceal,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Like those champions devoted and brave,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: When they plunged in the tyrant their steel,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: And to Athens deliverance gave. II Beloved heroes! your deathless souls roam

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: In the joy breathing isles of the blest;

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Where the mighty of old have their home—

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Where Achilles and Diomed rest. III In fresh myrtle my blade I'll entwine,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Like Harmodius, the gallant and good,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: When he made at the tutelar shrine

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: A libation of Tyranny's blood. IV Ye deliverers of Athens from shame!

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Ye avengers of Liberty's wrongs!

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Endless ages shall cherish your fame,

title: Hymn (translation from the Greek
line_text: Embalmed in their echoing songs! 1827 Contents p. 3

title: Dreams
line_text: Oh! that my young life were a lasting dream!

title: Dreams
line_text: My spirit not awakening, till the beam

title: Dreams
line_text: Of an Eternity should bring the morrow.

title: Dreams
line_text: Yes! though that long dream were of hopeless sorrow,

title: Dreams
line_text: 'Twere better than the cold reality

title: Dreams
line_text: Of waking life, to him whose heart must be,

title: Dreams
line_text: And hath been still, upon the lovely earth,

title: Dreams
line_text: A chaos of deep passion, from his birth.

title: Dreams
line_text: But should it be—that dream eternally

title: Dreams
line_text: Continuing—as dreams have been to me

title: Dreams
line_text: In my young boyhood—should it thus be given,

title: Dreams
line_text: 'Twere folly still to hope for higher Heaven.

title: Dreams
line_text: For I have revelled when the sun was bright

title: Dreams
line_text: I' the summer sky, in dreams of living light

title: Dreams
line_text: And loveliness,—have left my very heart Inclines of my imaginary apart 1 From mine own home, with beings that have been

title: Dreams
line_text: Of mine own thought—what more could I have seen?

title: Dreams
line_text: 'Twas once—and only once—and the wild hour

title: Dreams
line_text: From my remembrance shall not pass—some power

title: Dreams
line_text: Or spell had bound me—'twas the chilly wind

title: Dreams
line_text: Came o'er me in the night, and left behind

title: Dreams
line_text: Its image on my spirit—or the moon

title: Dreams
line_text: Shone on my slumbers in her lofty noon

title: Dreams
line_text: Too coldly—or the stars—howe'er it was

title: Dreams
line_text: That dream was that that night-wind—let it pass. I have been happy, though in a dream.

title: Dreams
line_text: I have been happy—and I love the theme:

title: Dreams
line_text: Dreams! in their vivid coloring of life

title: Dreams
line_text: As in that fleeting, shadowy, misty strife

title: Dreams
line_text: Of semblance with reality which brings

title: Dreams
line_text: To the delirious eye, more lovely things

title: Dreams
line_text: Of Paradise and Love—and all my own!—

title: Dreams
line_text: Than young Hope in his sunniest hour hath known. Footnote 1: In climes of mine imagining apart?—Ed. return Contents p. 3

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: How often we forget all time, when lone

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Admiring Nature's universal throne;

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Her woods—her wilds—her mountains—the intense

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Reply of Hers to Our intelligence! I In youth I have known one with whom the Earth

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: In secret communing held—as he with it,

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: In daylight, and in beauty, from his birth:

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Whose fervid, flickering torch of life was lit

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: From the sun and stars, whence he had drawn forth

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: A passionate light such for his spirit was fit—

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: And yet that spirit knew—not in the hour

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Of its own fervor—what had o'er it power. II Perhaps it may be that my mind is wrought To a ferver 1 by the moonbeam that hangs o'er,

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: But I will half believe that wild light fraught

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: With more of sovereignty than ancient lore

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Hath ever told—or is it of a thought

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: The unembodied essence, and no more

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: That with a quickening spell doth o'er us pass

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: As dew of the night-time, o'er the summer grass? III Doth o'er us pass, when, as th' expanding eye

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: To the loved object—so the tear to the lid

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Will start, which lately slept in apathy?

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: And yet it need not be—(that object) hid

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: From us in life—but common—which doth lie

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Each hour before us—but then only bid

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: With a strange sound, as of a harp-string broken

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: T' awake us—'Tis a symbol and a token— IV Of what in other worlds shall be—and given

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: In beauty by our God, to those alone

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Who otherwise would fall from life and Heaven

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Drawn by their heart's passion, and that tone,

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: That high tone of the spirit which hath striven

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Though not with Faith—with godliness—whose throne

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: With desperate energy 't hath beaten down;

title: "In Youth I have Known One"
line_text: Wearing its own deep feeling as a crown. Footnote 1: Query "fervor"?—Ed. return Contents p. 3

title: A Pæan
line_text: I How shall the burial rite be read?

title: A Pæan
line_text: The solemn song be sung?

title: A Pæan
line_text: The requiem for the loveliest dead,

title: A Pæan
line_text: That ever died so young? II Her friends are gazing on her,

title: A Pæan
line_text: And on her gaudy bier,

title: A Pæan
line_text: And weep!—oh! to dishonor

title: A Pæan
line_text: Dead beauty with a tear! III They loved her for her wealth—

title: A Pæan
line_text: And they hated her for her pride—

title: A Pæan
line_text: But she grew in feeble health,

title: A Pæan
line_text: And they love her—that she died. IV They tell me (while they speak

title: A Pæan
line_text: Of her "costly broider'd pall")

title: A Pæan
line_text: That my voice is growing weak—

title: A Pæan
line_text: That I should not sing at all— V Or that my tone should be

title: A Pæan
line_text: Tun'd to such solemn song

title: A Pæan
line_text: So mournfully—so mournfully,

title: A Pæan
line_text: That the dead may feel no wrong. VI But she is gone above,

title: A Pæan
line_text: With young Hope at her side,

title: A Pæan
line_text: And I am drunk with love

title: A Pæan
line_text: Of the dead, who is my bride.— VII Of the dead—dead who lies

title: A Pæan
line_text: All perfum'd there,

title: A Pæan
line_text: With the death upon her eyes.

title: A Pæan
line_text: And the life upon her hair. VIII Thus on the coffin loud and long

title: A Pæan
line_text: I strike—the murmur sent

title: A Pæan
line_text: Through the gray chambers to my song,

title: A Pæan
line_text: Shall be the accompaniment. IX Thou diedst in thy life's June—

title: A Pæan
line_text: But thou didst not die too fair:

title: A Pæan
line_text: Thou didst not die too soon,

title: A Pæan
line_text: Nor with too calm an air. X From more than friends on earth,

title: A Pæan
line_text: Thy life and love are riven,

title: A Pæan
line_text: To join the untainted mirth

title: A Pæan
line_text: Of more than thrones in heaven.— XI Therefore, to thee this night

title: A Pæan
line_text: I will no requiem raise,

title: A Pæan
line_text: But waft thee on thy flight,

title: A Pæan
line_text: With a Pæan of old days. Contents p. 3 Notes On the "Poems written in Youth" little comment is needed. This

line_text: section includes the pieces printed for the first volume of 1827 (which

title: A Pæan
line_text: was subsequently suppressed), such poems from the first and second

title: A Pæan
line_text: published volumes of 1829 and 1831 as have not already been given in

title: Alone
line_text: From childhood's hour I have not been

title: Alone
line_text: As others were—I have not seen

title: Alone
line_text: As others saw—I could not bring

title: Alone
line_text: My passions from a common spring—

title: Alone
line_text: From the same source I have not taken

title: Alone
line_text: My sorrow—I could not awaken

title: Alone
line_text: My heart to joy at the same tone—

title: Alone
line_text: And all I loved— I loved alone— Thou —in my childhood—in the dawn

title: Alone
line_text: Of a most stormy life—was drawn

title: Alone
line_text: From every depth of good and ill

title: Alone
line_text: The mystery which binds me still—

title: Alone
line_text: From the torrent, or the fountain—

title: Alone
line_text: From the red cliff of the mountain—

title: Alone
line_text: From the sun that round me roll'd

title: Alone
line_text: In its autumn tint of gold—

title: Alone
line_text: From the lightning in the sky

title: Alone
line_text: As it passed me flying by—

title: Alone
line_text: From the thunder and the storm—

title: Alone
line_text: And the cloud that took the form

title: Alone
line_text: (When the rest of Heaven was blue)

title: Alone
line_text: Of a demon in my view. March 17, 1829 Note Contents p. 3

title: To Isadore
line_text: I Beneath the vine-clad eaves,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Whose shadows fall before

title: To Isadore
line_text: Thy lowly cottage door—

title: To Isadore
line_text: Under the lilac's tremulous leaves—

title: To Isadore
line_text: Within thy snowy clasped hand

title: To Isadore
line_text: The purple flowers it bore.

title: To Isadore
line_text: Last eve in dreams, I saw thee stand,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Like queenly nymph from Fairy-land—

title: To Isadore
line_text: Enchantress of the flowery wand,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Most beauteous Isadore! II And when I bade the dream

title: To Isadore
line_text: Upon thy spirit flee,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Thy violet eyes to me

title: To Isadore
line_text: Upturned, did overflowing seem

title: To Isadore
line_text: With the deep, untold delight

title: To Isadore
line_text: Of Love's serenity;

title: To Isadore
line_text: Thy classic brow, like lilies white

title: To Isadore
line_text: And pale as the Imperial Night

title: To Isadore
line_text: Upon her throne, with stars bedight,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Enthralled my soul to thee! III Ah! ever I behold

title: To Isadore
line_text: Thy dreamy, passionate eyes,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Blue as the languid skies

title: To Isadore
line_text: Hung with the sunset's fringe of gold;

title: To Isadore
line_text: Now strangely clear thine image grows,

title: To Isadore
line_text: And olden memories

title: To Isadore
line_text: Are startled from their long repose

title: To Isadore
line_text: Like shadows on the silent snows

title: To Isadore
line_text: When suddenly the night-wind blows

title: To Isadore
line_text: Where quiet moonlight lies. IV Like music heard in dreams,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Like strains of harps unknown,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Of birds for ever flown,—

title: To Isadore
line_text: Audible as the voice of streams

title: To Isadore
line_text: That murmur in some leafy dell,

title: To Isadore
line_text: I hear thy gentlest tone,

title: To Isadore
line_text: And Silence cometh with her spell

title: To Isadore
line_text: Like that which on my tongue doth dwell,

title: To Isadore
line_text: When tremulous in dreams I tell

title: To Isadore
line_text: My love to thee alone! V In every valley heard,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Floating from tree to tree,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Less beautiful to me,

title: To Isadore
line_text: The music of the radiant bird,

title: To Isadore
line_text: Than artless accents such as thine

title: To Isadore
line_text: Whose echoes never flee!

title: To Isadore
line_text: Ah! how for thy sweet voice I pine:—

title: To Isadore
line_text: For uttered in thy tones benign

title: To Isadore
line_text: (Enchantress!) this rude name of mine

title: To Isadore
line_text: Doth seem a melody! Note Contents p. 3

title: The Village Street
line_text: In these rapid, restless shadows,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Once I walked at eventide,

title: The Village Street
line_text: When a gentle, silent maiden,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Walked in beauty at my side.

title: The Village Street
line_text: She alone there walked beside me

title: The Village Street
line_text: All in beauty, like a bride.

title: The Village Street
line_text: Pallidly the moon was shining

title: The Village Street
line_text: On the dewy meadows nigh;

title: The Village Street
line_text: On the silvery, silent rivers,

title: The Village Street
line_text: On the mountains far and high,—

title: The Village Street
line_text: On the ocean's star-lit waters,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Where the winds a-weary die.

title: The Village Street
line_text: Slowly, silently we wandered

title: The Village Street
line_text: From the open cottage door,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Underneath the elm's long branches

title: The Village Street
line_text: To the pavement bending o'er;

title: The Village Street
line_text: Underneath the mossy willow

title: The Village Street
line_text: And the dying sycamore.

title: The Village Street
line_text: With the myriad stars in beauty

title: The Village Street
line_text: All bedight, the heavens were seen,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Radiant hopes were bright around me,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Like the light of stars serene;

title: The Village Street
line_text: Like the mellow midnight splendor

title: The Village Street
line_text: Of the Night's irradiate queen.

title: The Village Street
line_text: Audibly the elm-leaves whispered

title: The Village Street
line_text: Peaceful, pleasant melodies,

title: The Village Street
line_text: Like the distant murmured music

title: The Village Street
line_text: Of unquiet, lovely seas;

title: The Village Street
line_text: While the winds were hushed in slumber
